title: WhatsApp → n8n → Home Assistant
description: Bi-directional automation pipeline, message parsing, and service execution. The Basis for the Metaglasses
whatILearned: Designing robust, bi-directional message flows between cloud services and a local home automation stack.
Handling WhatsApp API quirks, retries, and error states in long-running automations.
Structuring n8n workflows so they stay maintainable as more devices and triggers are added.
bestFor: Home Assistant users who want to trigger and control automations over WhatsApp from anywhere.

featureToggle.reason: Core automation backbone and foundation for multiple other experiments.

futurePlans: Add templated flows for common Home Assistant routines (lights, climate, media).
Introduce a simple configuration UI so non-technical users can customize commands.
Experiment with multi-user support and basic access control per WhatsApp account.
statusForContributors: Actively accepting PRs, especially around reliability, configuration UX, and new example flows.

title: Meta Smart Glasses WhatsApp bot
description: Experimental overlays for Meta Display Glasses using data relayed through WhatsApp API.
whatILearned: Exploring the practical limits of Meta smart glasses integrations using indirect data channels.
Prototyping low-friction, heads-up notifications powered by existing automation pipelines.
Understanding where platform limitations block deeper system integration.
bestFor: Early adopters with Meta smart glasses who want proof-of-concept HUD-style notifications powered by WhatsApp and Home Assistant.

featureToggle.reason: Interesting concept, but currently blocked by platform support.

futurePlans: Revisit when Meta exposes better APIs or companion integrations for real-time overlays.
Extract any reusable patterns into the core WhatsApp → Home Assistant project.
Document current constraints so others can build on the idea if platform access improves.
statusForContributors: Ideas welcome, stalled due to platform limits and missing Meta support.

changelog.note: Unable to proceed due to lack of Meta support

title: Movie/Series Tracker - Android Version
description: Android movie database engine using TMDb, caching, and multi-page settings.
whatILearned: Designing an offline-friendly media tracker with API-backed search and local caching.
Balancing flexible filtering and sorting with a simple Android-friendly UI.
Managing TMDb usage limits and data structures efficiently on mobile devices.
bestFor: Android users who want a lightweight, customizable way to track movies and series using TMDb.

featureToggle.reason: Polished mobile experience that pairs well with the Linux desktop version.

futurePlans: Add sync between Android and Linux versions using a simple export/import or cloud backend.
Introduce watchlists per profile and basic stats (time watched, genres, etc.).
Polish theming and consider Material You-style integration for modern Android devices.
statusForContributors: Actively accepting PRs for UI/UX polish, sync options, and new filtering features.

title: Movie/Series Tracker - Linux version
description: Linux *via QT* movie database engine using TMDb, caching, and multi-page settings.
whatILearned: Building a cross-platform movie tracker UI with Qt and QML on desktop.
Structuring TMDb-backed search and caching for a keyboard-and-mouse workflow.
Keeping a codebase flexible enough to share concepts with the Android version.
bestFor: Linux desktop users who want a Qt-based movie and series tracker integrated into their workflow.

featureToggle.reason: Desktop companion to the Android tracker, good showcase of Qt/QML work.

futurePlans: Improve keyboard shortcuts and power-user features for fast library navigation.
Add optional integration with local media libraries or players.
Align UI patterns with the Android version for a cohesive cross-device experience.
statusForContributors: Actively accepting PRs to refine the Qt UI, performance, and advanced power-user features.

title: Analog Lofi Linux Clock plasmoid
description: Linux analog clock widget based on windows ME widget for kde Plasma desktop
whatILearned: Porting a nostalgic widget aesthetic into a modern KDE Plasma plasmoid.
Handling Plasma 6 changes, configuration persistence, and performance tuning.
Refining visuals like fonts, aspect ratio, and repaint timing for a smooth analog clock.
bestFor: KDE Plasma users who love retro, lofi-style desktop widgets and want a lightweight analog clock.

featureToggle.reason: Polished, shippable plasmoid that showcases Plasma 6 support.

futurePlans: Add optional themes (color variants, more nostalgic skins).
Expose more fine-grained configuration options without cluttering the default experience.
Package for easy installation from KDE’s widget ecosystem or store.
statusForContributors: Looking for testers on Plasma 6 and PRs for themes, translations, and minor UI refinements.

changelog.note: Version 1.1, Plasma 6 update. Configuration handling corrected. Tooltip updates fixed. Adaptive repaint timing added. Performance improved. Font handling hardened. Aspect-ratio resizing stabilized. File structure cleaned up. Deprecated code removed.

title: Linux Penny Arcade Comic Displayer
description: Linux widget that displays the latest penny arcade comics
whatILearned: Building a content-driven plasmoid that fetches and displays web comic updates.
Dealing with remote content reliability and making the widget fail gracefully.
Optimizing layout for different panel sizes and Plasma configurations.
bestFor: KDE Plasma users who want Penny Arcade comics integrated directly into their desktop.

featureToggle.reason: Fun, niche plasmoid that’s stable enough for everyday use.

futurePlans: Support additional web comics via configuration or presets.
Add archive navigation and quick jump to the full website when desired.
Improve caching and network error messaging for unreliable connections.
statusForContributors: Looking for testers on Plasma 6 and PRs to extend comic sources and improve UX.

title: Conky haloween clock
whatILearned: Creating themed, seasonal desktop widgets using Conky on Linux.
Balancing visual flair with readability for a digital clock overlay.
Packaging and documenting a small cosmetic widget for other users.
bestFor: Linux and Conky users who want a Halloween-themed, seasonal clock on their desktop.

featureToggle.reason: Fun seasonal widget that’s easy for others to pick up and modify.

futurePlans: Add more seasonal variants (winter, spring, generic spooky themes).
Provide configuration snippets for popular desktop environments.
Publish a small gallery of themes so users can quickly swap looks.
statusForContributors: Actively accepting PRs for new themes, configuration presets, and small quality-of-life tweaks.
